lines.text: Enter HERO, MARGARET, and URSULA

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire her to rise.

lines.speaker: ursula
lines.text: I will, lady.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: And bid her come hither.

lines.speaker: ursula
lines.text: Well.
Exit

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Troth, I think your other rabato were better.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: No, pray thee, good Meg, Ill wear this.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: By my troth, s not so good and I warrant your cousin will say so.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: My cousins a fool, and thou art another: Ill wear none but this.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a thought browner and your gowns a most rare fashion, i faith. I saw the Duchess of Milans gown that they praise so.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: O, that exceeds, they say.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: By my troth, s but a nightgown in respect of yours: cloth o gold, and cuts, and laced with silver, set with pearls, down sleeves, side sleeves, and skirts, round underborne with a bluish tinsel: but for a fine, quaint, graceful and excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on t.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: God give me joy to wear it! for my heart is exceeding heavy.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: Fie upon thee! art not ashamed

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Of what, lady of speaking honourably Is not marriage honourable in a beggar Is not your lord honourable without marriage I think you would have me say, saving your reverence, a husband: and bad thinking do not wrest true speaking, Ill offend nobody: is there any harm in the heavier for a husband None, I think, and it be the right husband and the right wife otherwise tis light, and not heavy: ask my Lady Beatrice else here she comes.
Enter BEATRICE

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: Good morrow, coz.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: Why how now do you speak in the sick tune

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Claps into Light o love that goes without a burden: do you sing it, and Ill dance it.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Ye light o love, with your heels! then, if your husband have stables enough, youll see he shall lack no barns.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Tis almost five oclock, cousin tis time you were ready. By my troth, I am exceeding ill: heighho!

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: For the letter that begins them all, H.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Well, and you be not turned Turk, theres no more sailing by the star.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: What means the fool, trow

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Nothing I but God send every one their hearts desire!

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: These gloves the count sent me they are an excellent perfume.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I am stuffed, cousin I cannot smell.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: A maid, and stuffed! theres goodly catching of cold.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: O, God help me! God help me! how long have you professed apprehension

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Even since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: It is not seen enough, you should wear it in your cap. By my troth, I am sick.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Get you some of this distilled Carduus Benedictus, and lay it to your heart: it is the only thing for a qualm.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: There thou prickest her with a thistle.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Benedictus! why Benedictus you have some moral in this Benedictus.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Moral! no, by my troth, I have no moral meaning I meant, plain holythistle. You may think perchance that I think you are in love: nay, byr lady, I am not such a fool to think what I list, nor I list not to think what I can, nor indeed I cannot think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you are in love or that you will be in love or that you can be in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he become a man: he swore he would never marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without grudging: and how you may be converted I know not, but methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: Not a false gallop.
Reenter URSULA

lines.speaker: ursula
lines.text: Madam, withdraw: the prince, the count, Signior Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the town, are come to fetch you to church.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.
Exeunt
